positive.headline: Bellingham sent off as Real Madrid held by Osasuna
positive.summary: Jude Bellingham has been sent off twice in his Real Madrid career. The England midfielder was shown a straight red in the 39th minute for foul and abusive language towards referee Jose Luis Munuera Montero. Bellingham's only previous dismissal for Real came after the final whistle in a 2-2 draw at Valencia in March 2024.

positive.headline: British PM says heâll join other European leaders for meeting, calling it a âonce in a generation momentâ for their national security
positive.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to join European leaders at an emergency summit in Paris on Monday. Starmer: We cannot allow any divisions in the alliance to distract from the external enemies we face. This comes as Trump speaks to Russian President Vladimir Putin as he pushes for a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine.

positive.headline: Zelensky warns days of guaranteed US support for Europe are over, as Kellogg says Europeans wonât be at table for peace talks
positive.summary: Zelensky urges Europe to band together to create a united army and foreign policy. He spoke in a week when a phone call between Russian President Vladimir Putin and US counterpart   raised fears in Kyiv that it was being frozen out of negotiations. The White House also downplayed the prospects of Ukraine joining NATO.

positive.headline:
Video
                    Author reacts to RFK Jr. becoming HHS secretary
                        3:35
positive.summary: ParentData CEO Emily Oster joins CNNâs Paula Reid to discuss Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s confirmation as Health and Human Services secretary. Oster: “We’re all in this together.”

positive.headline: Elon Muskâs dream comes true: The federal board that protects workers does not exist, at least for now
positive.summary: The National Labor Relations Board, the independent agency that is supposed to enforce labor laws for most American workers, has been essentially shut down. President Donald Trump fired one of its board members, leaving it without the quorum it needs to function. The NLRB oversees elections to form unions and investigates complaints about unfair labor practices.

positive.headline: Saudi Arabia seeks to mediate between Trump and Iran on new nuclear deal
positive.summary: Riyadh is open to mediating between the U.S. and Iran over Iran's nuclear program. It is unclear whether Saudi Arabia has made a formal offer. Iran's supreme leader has said talks with the United States are "not smart"

positive.headline:
Video
                    From the Pope to Elon Musk: See NewsNightsâ most heated discussions of the week
                        4:58
positive.summary: CNN NewsNight is CNN.com's weekly, offbeat look at the day's top stories. This week, we look at political ads and Elon Musk's role in the White House. Follow CNN NewsNight on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

positive.headline:
Video
Videos show roads flooded as Tennessee-Kentucky region undergoes rare, high risk flood alert
                        0:51
positive.summary: A rare level 4 of 4 high risk of flooding rainfall is in place for more than 1.5 million people in parts of northwestern Tennessee and western Kentucky. The storm is expected to reach   as it barrels through much of the eastern US.

positive.headline:
50 years of love (and the research to prove it)
            
                
                    Feb 15, 2025
positive.summary: Volunteers in every state are delivering roses and heartfelt cards to senior citizens. An animal shelter is playing matchmaker across the country. The psychologists behind the famous " " are celebrating 50 years of marriage. A couple bonded over their love of this romantic comedy, so the proposal had to be perfect.

positive.headline:
Love and robots: How AI is changing the dating scene
            
                
                    Feb 11, 2025
positive.summary: Artificial intelligence is promising to switch things up in the dating world once more. Marketing professional shares how she has used AI in her dating life. AI expert explains how this technology is changing dating apps, and the people who use them. What questions do you have about the technology in your life? Email us at  .

positive.headline:
Gallery
                    Elon Muskâs son steals spotlight. Surfer rides perfect wave in Hawaii. The week in photos
positive.summary: The Philadelphia Eagles beat the Kansas City Chiefs 40-22. The game was a rematch of the Super Bowl two years ago, which the Chiefs won. Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts threw for two touchdowns and ran for one on his way to winning.

positive.headline: New York Giants ownership is exploring the possibility of selling minority stake in franchise
positive.summary: The New York Giants ownership is considering the sale of a minority stake in the franchise. The Giants did not outline the percentage of the stake potentially for sale, but did confirm they had acquired the services of an investment bank. John Mara and Steve Tisch, on behalf of their families, currently own 50% each.

positive.headline: âWhite Lotusâ is expected to lure more tourists to Thailand. These are the locations featured on season 3 of the hit show
positive.summary: The third season of the Emmy-winning HBO show premieres on February 16. Carrie Coon, Michelle Monaghan, Jason Isaacs, Leslie Bibb, Walton Goggins, Pa are among the cast members. The show is expected to be spicier than ever as it takes viewers to Thailand.

positive.headline: Chinaâs animated blockbuster smashed box office records at home. Now itâs hitting Western cinemas
positive.summary: An unruly Chinese boy who battles dragons and defies destiny has made his way to Western cinema screens after smashing box office records in China. The animated blockbuster loosely based on Chinese mythology, is now the worldâs highest-grossing movie of all time in a single market, racking up a staggering $1.4 billion in ticket sales.

positive.headline: Dolly Parton harmonizes with Sabrina Carpenter for cute, cleaned-up redux of âPlease Please Pleaseâ
positive.summary: Jolene Carpenter has released a new version of her hit song âPlease Please Pleaseâ�ai on Thursday night. The song features the one and only  , who compliments Carpenter’s vocals on the track with a beautiful falsetto.

positive.headline: Newly discovered fungus turns cave-dwelling spiders into âzombiesâ
positive.summary: Gibellula attenboroughii is a previously unknown species of fungus. The fungus lures spiders out of their webs before instigating an untimely death. The way in which the fungus affects the arachnidâs brain is still a mystery.

positive.headline: Largest celestial object of its kind discovered in the distant universe
positive.summary: The ancient object formed when the universe was less than 10% of its current age of 13.8 billion years. Until now, these faraway colossal radio jets released not long after the big bang have been elusive. How they are created remains an enigma, according to lead author Anniek Gloudemans.

positive.headline: âThe greatest product placement everâ: How a TV show changed an industry
positive.summary: Back in 1970, an estimated 500,000 people went on a cruise holiday. That figure had jumped to five million by 1997. The Love Boat first aired in 1977 and went on to become one of the most successful shows in TV history during its decade-long run.

positive.headline: See all the best looks â and celebrity appearances â at New York Fashion Week
positive.summary: New York Fashion Week concluded Tuesday. Thom Browne and Calvin Klein showed their latest collections. Several major labels and cult mainstays were absent from the schedule following the departure of their creative directors. Some heritage brands like Tommy Hilfiger and Ralph Lauren skipped the season entirely.

positive.headline: The secret to great sex isnât really a secret. Itâs asking the right question, 81-year-old sex professor says
positive.summary: World-renowned human sexuality professor says it's no big secret how to have great sex. Ask your partner: âHow do you like to be touched?â�ai and “Here’s how I like to being touched.” Some students have followed his advice and reported back to him over the years.

positive.headline: How much coffee is too much, according to a doctor
positive.summary: Recent research has generated new buzz about caffeine consumption. Drinking coffee in the morning is especially beneficial in reducing cardiovascular disease and premature death. How much coffee is good for most people, according to these studies and how much is too much? Should some people be especially careful about coffee consumption? And if you don’t like coffee, are there similar benefits from drinking tea or other beverages?

positive.headline: 50 years of love (and the research to prove it)
positive.summary: Volunteers in every state are delivering roses and heartfelt cards to senior citizens. An animal shelter is playing matchmaker across the country. The psychologists behind the famous " " are celebrating 50 years of marriage. A couple bonded over their love of this romantic comedy, so the proposal had to be perfect.

positive.headline: Why crunchy conservatives love RFK Jr.
positive.summary: The rise of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and the conservative “Make America Healthy Again’ movement is reclaiming what it means to be ‘crunchy’ Audie talks with Kiera Butler, a Mother Jones senior editor and reporter deeply embedded in the world of the conservative right's wellness trends.

positive.headline: Love and robots: How AI is changing the dating scene
positive.summary: Artificial intelligence is promising to switch things up in the dating world once more. Marketing professional shares how she has used AI in her dating life. AI expert explains how this technology is changing dating apps, and the people who use them. What questions do you have about the technology in your life? Email us at  .

positive.headline: Mac McClung Wins Slam Dunk Contest
positive.summary: Orlando Magic guard Mac McClung won the 2025 NBA Slam Dunk Contest. McClung became the first player to claim the title in three consecutive years. He received flawless scores on each of his four dunks throughout the evening. This included both of his finishes in the final round.

positive.headline: Bills mailroom employee gifted car after Josh Allen speech
positive.summary: Buffalo Bills mailroom employee Roderick "Slick Rick" Morrow has been gifted a free car. Morrow became well-known after quarterback Josh Allen shouted him out during his NFL MVP acceptance speech. West Herr Auto Group gifted Morrow a 2017 Chevy Traverse and made a presentation.

positive.headline:
Video
                    We third-wheeled on a date in a retirement community. Did they fall in love?
                        4:02
positive.summary: Ted (72) and Doris (age is just a number) were set up by staff at a Valentine's dating event. The RiverSpring Living retirement community in the Bronx, New York, has long encouraged sex, intimacy and companionships among its elderly residents.

positive.headline: Easy potluck recipes that are sure to please a crowd
positive.summary: We rounded up some of our favorite dishes that are perfect for the potluck. These recipes are all guaranteedÂ  Â favorites, travel well, and make a big portion (or can be easily scaled up) Cauliflower takes the place of potato to offer a high fiber version of the tasty classic.

positive.headline:
Gallery
                    The best photos from the 2025 Super Bowl
positive.summary: The Philadelphia Eagles beat the Kansas City Chiefs 40-22. The game was a rematch of the Super Bowl two years ago, which the Chiefs won 38-35. Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts threw for two touchdowns and ran for one. The Eagles defense suffocated the Chiefs offense and star quarterback Patrick Mahomes.

positive.headline:
Gallery
                    The Super Bowl halftime show, in pictures
positive.summary: Kendrick Lamar is one of hip-hopâs most celebrated artists. His performance came a week after he won song and record of the year for his hit "Not Like Us" He made his Super Bowl halftime show debut in 2022.

positive.headline: Incredible survival tales of animal encounters, from sharks to bears to bison
positive.summary: A Chilean father recently   a humpback whale briefly swallowed his son while kayaking in Patagonia. Two American tourists share another harrowing story of the day they were attacked by a shark in the Bahamas. A video of a dangerous encounter with a territorial bison went viral back in 2022. Here are our  if you get yourself in a pickle.

positive.headline: Kasparov, Karpov and the KGB? Four decades on from the most controversial chess match of all time
positive.summary: Russian-born grandmaster Gennadi Sosonko was an enemy of the Soviet Union. He was in Switzerland when he heard that the 1984-85 match in Moscow had been abandoned. The match had lasted five months, longer than any other World Championship before or since.

positive.headline: The scent of a mummy: Research discovers ancient Egyptian remains smell nice
positive.summary: Mummies as old as 5,000 years found to smell good. Researchers at University College London say they were surprised at the pleasantness of them. Floral notes were also detected, which could be from pine and juniper resins used in embalming.

positive.headline: Skip to main content
positive.summary: Sophia embarks on the gruelling journey of harvesting her eggs. She’s in her 30s and feels ambivalent about having kids, so will this safeguard her future? Remarkable documentary Harvest is her personal diary of this time.

positive.headline: Share stories with the Guardian securely and confidentially
positive.summary: SecureDrop allows you to safely send us messages and documents. All we get is what you send us, and a codename that allows us to reply to you. To prevent interception at our end, we decrypt what you sent us on a computer that is kept.

positive.headline: ‘It can be really frightening’: knowing the common signs that a loved one is dying can help in their final days
positive.summary: Being with her in the months, days and hours up to her death from cancer was the hardest thing I have ever done. It also felt like the most important. And there was one piece of information that allowed us to recognise what was happening at a crucial moment.

positive.headline: They say we don’t like sex, drugs, democracy or DIY. But here’s how we in gen Z really feel
positive.summary: Recent surveys claim to have discovered a lot of alarming things about my generation. But they’re not telling you the whole story. Nearly a quarter of us canât change a lightbulb. A fair chunk can’t identify a flathead screwdriver, and a fifth don”t even know what a spanner is.

positive.headline: Sprint sensation Gout Gout smashes Noah Lyles’ personal best time for 400m
positive.summary: Gout clocked 46.20s, almost a second under Lyles’ personal best for the distance. It is the fastest under-18 time by an Australian for 35 years. Gout recently returned from a Florida training camp with Lyles and the American’s coach Lance Brauman.

positive.headline: Back to top
positive.summary: Sophia embarks on the gruelling journey of harvesting her eggs. She’s in her 30s and feels ambivalent about having kids, so will this safeguard her future? Remarkable documentary Harvest is her personal diary of this time.

positive.headline: Spelling BeeHow many words can you make with 7 letters?
positive.summary: Since the launch of The Crossword in 1942, The Times has captivated solvers by providing engaging word and logic games. In 2014, we introduced The Mini Crossword, followed by Spelling Bee, Letter Boxed and Tiles. In early 2022, we proudly added Wordle to our collection. Since then we have created Connections and Strands.

positive.headline: Sudan army retakes more of capital Khartoum from RSF
positive.summary: Sudanese army advances on Khartoum, retakes territory from paramilitary group. Rapid Support Forces still controls some key positions, including the central market, the presidential palace, and some of the southern and western residential districts. It also holds parts of the central region of Kordofan, most of the western region of Darfur, and is besieging the army and its allies in the city of el-Fashir.

positive.headline: ICC Champions Trophy 2025: Top five players to watch
positive.summary: The International Cricket Council’s (ICC) Champions Trophy begins in Pakistan on February 19. This edition comes after an eight-year gap since the tournament was last staged in 2017, when Pakistan lifted the trophy in England. Al Jazeera Sport has picked the top five players to look out for this time around.

positive.headline: World Cup holders Australia 107 all out in final Champions Trophy warm-up
positive.summary: Sri Lanka beat Australia by 174 runs in their second one-day international. Kusal Mendis top-scored with 101 and was well supported by Charith Asalanka. Australia lost their last seven wickets for 28 runs to be bowled out for 107.

positive.headline: ICC Champions Trophy 2025: Top five players to watch
positive.summary: The International Cricket Council’s (ICC) Champions Trophy begins in Pakistan on February 19. This edition comes after an eight-year gap since the tournament was last staged in 2017, when Pakistan lifted the trophy in England. Al Jazeera Sport has picked the top five players to look out for this time around.

positive.headline: IN PHOTOS | This week's most compelling images
positive.summary: Photographers from CBC News, The Canadian Press, Reuters and others document our changing world every day. Here’s a selection of the week's top images. It is a priority for CBC to create a website that is accessible to all Canadians including people with visual, hearing, motor and cognitive challenges.

positive.headline: Ukraine needs 'real security guarantees' before any peace talks with Russia, Zelenskyy tells Vance
positive.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with U.S. Vice-President J.D. Vance in Munich. He said he will only agree to meet in-person with Russian leader Vladimir Putin after a common plan is negotiated. Vance, for his part, said the Trump administration is committed to finding a lasting peace.

positive.headline: Igloo recalls more than 1M coolers after handle hazard causes fingertip amputations
positive.summary: Igloo is recalling more than 1 million of its coolers sold across Canada, the U.S. and Mexico. A tow handle can pinch users' fingertips against the product, posing potential amputation and other crushing risks. The coolers were sold at major retailers like Costco, Target, Dick's and Amazon between 2019 and 2025.

neutral.headline: Mapping China's influence around the Panama Canal
neutral.summary: US remains the main user of the canal, but Chinese involvement has grown. Up to 14,000 ships use the 51-mile (82km) passage each year. It links the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans across the Central American country. Panama left the partnership earlier this month amid US pre-emption.

neutral.headline:
Trending
DOGE policies and court challenges
neutral.summary: Government attorneys tasked with defending Trump's agenda have been put in an extremely challenging position. One judge scolded them for failing to flesh out legal arguments in writing. Court hearings have dragged on for hours because the lawyers are unable to get their clients on the phone to weigh in.

neutral.headline: NBA All-Star weekend
neutral.summary: Golden State Warriors star will make his 11th All-Star appearance. The Bay Area hosts the event, an opportunity he sees as both exciting and surreal. Curry: "Itâs a busy week, but it’s not home"

neutral.headline: âCake Banditâ opossum
neutral.summary: Kim Doggett bought the chocolate mousse cake from Costco. The opossum was admitted to Nebraska Wildlife Rehab on February 10. Fans have flooded the rescue service's Facebook page with messages of support for the viral cake bandit. "I get it gurl. I get it,â one commenter said.

neutral.headline: Trump officials to travel to Saudi Arabia for Russia-Ukraine talks
neutral.summary: Top U.S. officials to meet with Russian officials in Saudi Arabia to discuss Ukraine. The meeting is expected to take place in the coming days, sources tell CNN. The Kremlin is assembling a high-level team to engage in direct talks, sources say.

neutral.headline:
Video
                    Zelensky reveals to Amanpour what he believes Putin thinks of Trump
                        0:37
neutral.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky spoke to CNNâs Christiane Amanpour. US President Donald Trump also spoke to Amanpour about Russian President Vladimir Putin. The interview is part of CNN’s weekly Newsquiz series, which airs Sundays at 8 p.m. ET.

neutral.headline: McConnell bucks Trump and the evolving GOP
neutral.summary: Mitch McConnell was a generational force for the Republican Party. Now heâs the odd man out. He has cast a trio of votes against Trump’s Cabinet nominees. He opposed Pete Hegseth for defense secretary, citing his lack of experience.

neutral.headline:
For Subscribers
                    The American shopping mall is being reinvented
neutral.summary: American malls were never dead. The decades-old design just needed to be revisited. Malls were once home to major department stores, until the convenience of e-commerce drew shoppers away. Mixed-use model combines apartment units, fitness clubs, hotels, medical centers, office units and retail.

neutral.headline: âCake Banditâ opossum hospitalized after indulging in an entire Costco cake
neutral.summary: Kim Doggett bought the chocolate mousse cake from Costco. The opossum was admitted to Nebraska Wildlife Rehab on February 10. Fans have flooded the rescue service's Facebook page with messages of support for the viral cake bandit. "I get it gurl. I get it,â one commenter said.

neutral.headline:
Video
Andrew McCabe calls Kristi Noemâs FBI comments âtotally unprecedentedâ
                        2:11
neutral.summary: The FBI is pushing back against US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem's suggestion that corrupt agents leaked details of an immigration raid. Former FBI deputy director Andrew McCabe reacts and explains the seriousness of the allegation. The FBI says her suggestion that âcorruptâ agents leaked information was “deeply irresponsible.

neutral.headline: Fast-moving Trump DOGE policies and court challenges leave DOJ lawyers twisting in the wind
neutral.summary: Government attorneys tasked with defending Trump's agenda have been put in an extremely challenging position. One judge scolded them for failing to flesh out legal arguments in writing. Court hearings have dragged on for hours because the lawyers are unable to get their clients on the phone to weigh in.

neutral.headline: Who is Friedrich Merz, Merkelâs rival and German election frontrunner?
neutral.summary: Friedrich Merz is the favorite to become the countryâs next chancellor in the federal election on February 23. The 69-year-old veteran politician has a hardline stance on migration and a love of aviation. His long-time rival’s decision to leave the top job in 2021 prompted Merz to come out of political hibernation.

neutral.headline:
She arranged a date with a guy she met on a plane. When he didnât show, she unexpectedly met her future husband
            
                
                    Feb 10, 2025
neutral.summary: Italian traveler Cristina Farina arrived in London in the summer of 1984, only to be stood up by a man she met on an airplane. Cristina started chatting with American stranger Matt Reineke in London’s Trafalgar Square, changing the course of their lives.

neutral.headline: Asteroid 2024 YR4 could hit Earth in 7 years. Hereâs what could happen â and whatâs being done
neutral.summary: Asteroid has on average a 2% chance of hitting Earth in 2032. Asteroid is estimated to be 131 to 295 feet (40 to 90 meters) wide. Asteroids that are 1 kilometer across or larger could have a devastating impact.

neutral.headline: An eruption is possible at Alaskaâs Mount Spurr. What we know about the volcano
neutral.summary: Hundreds of small earthquakes have occurred beneath Mount Spurr. The volcano is located in the volcanically active Aleutian Arc, 75 miles west of Anchorage. Experts have also observed ground deformations. The rising magma can heat up surrounding areas on the way to the surface.

neutral.headline: US athlete smashes 21-year-old world record
neutral.summary: US middle-distance star Grant Fisher breaks 5,000-meter indoor world record. The 21-year-old breaks the previous mark set by Ethiopiaâs Kenenisa Bekele in 2004. Fisher won two bronze medals at the   in Paris.

neutral.headline:
Video
                    âHave I Got News For Youâ comedians react to RFK Jr. confirmation
                        0:44
neutral.summary: Panelists join Roy Wood Jr., Amber Ruffin and Michael Black on "Have I Got News For You" They react to the confirmation hearing of RFK Jr. as Health and Human Services secretary. Watch the full episodes on 2025 Cable News Network.

neutral.headline:
Quiz
                    The average score for this weekâs news quiz is 8.2. Can you do better?
neutral.summary: February’s full and a parade of planets were visible for lucky skygazers this week. Certain canned tuna products sold at Costco, Trader Joe's, Walmart and other retailers were recalled. President Trump said negotiations to end the Ukraine war will start "immediately"

neutral.headline: Weeks from homecoming, Boeing Starliner astronauts want to set the record straight
neutral.summary: NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore want to set the record straight. The duo made the remarks in an interview with CNNâs Anderson Cooper on Thursday. Wilmore added a request: “If you’ll help us change the rhetoric, help uschange the narrative.”

neutral.headline: Record-breaking âghost particleâ detected in the Mediterranean Sea
neutral.summary: The neutrino is 30 times more energetic than any of the few hundreds of previously detected neutrinos. Neutrinos arrive at Earth from the far reaches of the cosmos, have almost no mass. The particles travel through the most extreme environments, including stars, planets and entire galaxies.

neutral.headline: Sea turtles âdanceâ when their superpower leads them to food
neutral.summary: loggerheads learn the magnetic fields of specific geographic locations. This superpower likely helps them get back to ecologically important areas for nesting and feeding. Researchers found captive juvenile loggerheads respond to magnetic conditioning by what the team described as “dancingâ in anticipation of food.

neutral.headline: He got her a gold bracelet for Valentineâs Day. She âthought he was crazy,â but hereâs where they are 35 years later
neutral.summary: Anita Hansen, then in her early 20s, was studying French at college in Denmark. The university had arranged for Anita and her fellow students to spend a couple of days in Paris. On her first afternoon off from classes, Anita persuaded a classmate to head up the Eiffel Tower.

neutral.headline: This new plane could open a flood of new transatlantic flights
neutral.summary: Aer Lingus launches its first nonstop flight to Nashville from Dublin in April. The new flight is possible with a new, longer-range plane from Airbus: the A321XLR. The derivative of the popular A321neo can fly further than any other single-aisle plane on the market.

neutral.headline: Airbus gets on board with double-level airplane seating
neutral.summary: Aviation start-up Chaise Longue announced today it’s exploring some early stage concepts with aviation giant Airbus. The collaboration with an aircraft manufacturing heavyweight is a significant step in this seat designâs journey from concept to potential in-air reality.

neutral.headline: From rooftops to remote islands, this city has basketball courts everywhere
neutral.summary: American photographer Austin Bell took over 58,000 photos of 2,549 colorful basketball courts in Hong Kong. Bell estimates that the city has more outdoor courts than even New York or Los Angeles. The project spread across three years due to the city’s changing climate.

neutral.headline: Dressing Bridget Jones in her 50s: The âFrazzled Englishwomanâ grows up
neutral.summary: RenÃ©e Zellweger returns as Bridget Jones in the film adaptation of Helen Fielding’s “Bridget Jonesâs Diary.” It is her fourth turn as an endearing, klutzy character looking for love. costume designer Rachael Fleming sought to give Jones a pragmatic, somewhat disheveled look.

neutral.headline:
Video
Inside the ÃlysÃ©e Palaceâs art collection
                        1:38
neutral.summary: ThelysÃ©e Palace is the official residence of the President of France - Emmanuel Macron. During his time in office, Macron has combined the classical style of the palace with contemporary and modern art and design. Macron took Richard Quest on a tour, to see some of the artworks on show.

neutral.headline: German chancellor hits back at Vance comments
neutral.summary: US Vice President JD Vance spoke at the Munich Security Conference on Friday. He accused European allies of suppressing free speech and losing control of immigration. Vance met with Alternative for Germany (AfD) co-leader Alice Weidel at the sidelines of the conference.

neutral.headline: She arranged a date with a guy she met on a plane. When he didnât show, she unexpectedly met her future husband
neutral.summary: Italian traveler Cristina Farina arrived in London in the summer of 1984, only to be stood up by a man she met on an airplane. Cristina started chatting with American stranger Matt Reineke in London’s Trafalgar Square, changing the course of their lives.

neutral.headline: Relax, jealousy is normal
neutral.summary: Research shows humans experience this emotion even before they can crawl. CNN chief medical correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta sits down with psychologist Dr. Joli Hamilton to demystify jealousy. The complex emotion is not only natural but could actually be beneficial.

neutral.headline:
Video
                    Video: New Yorkers rush to help mother give birth on subway
                        0:57
neutral.summary: Dramatic footage captures the moment a group of subway riders in New York rush to aid a woman as she gave birth on the train. The woman was rushed to the hospital after giving birth to a baby girl on a New York City subway train.

neutral.headline:
Video
                    Driver jumps out of SUV moments before train crashes into it
                        0:41
neutral.summary: Surveillance video captured the moment a driver jumped out of an SUV seconds before a train smashed into it. No one was hurt but damage to the train is estimated to be into â6-figures. In addition to the SUV and train, the crossing gate arms and the crossing’s post were also heavily damaged.

neutral.headline: Foolproof fudge recipes anyone can make
neutral.summary: Homemade fudge is one of our favorite treats all year round. Don’t stir the sugar mixture as it boils. Let it cook (undisturbed) to 234 degrees F and your final candy will have the crystal-free texture youâre looking for.

neutral.headline: How to wash a wool sweater
neutral.summary: Washing wool without shrinking it is not as tricky as you might think. By hand-washing your wool sweater, you can maintain its size and ensure it stays as soft as the first time you wore it. Follow these steps to safely clean and remove stains from wool sweaters.

neutral.headline: Tracking Trumpâs executive actions
neutral.summary: President Donald Trump has vowed to enact a sweeping agenda and reshape the federal government. CNN analyzed the dozens of executive actions and determined a singular category. In many cases, however, the executive actions could fit into several categories, but we have chosen only one for this analysis.

neutral.headline: Send us your questions about Trumpâs second term
neutral.summary: Let us know your questions about Trumpâs moves in his second term. Elon Musk has been given power to try to remake the US government. Trump is using executive power in unique new ways to challenge how Americans view the US Constitution.

neutral.headline: The real reason behind the DeepSeek hype, according to AI experts
neutral.summary: DeepSeek grabbed headlines in late January with its R1 AI model, which the company says can roughly match the performance of Open AIâs o1 model at a fraction of the cost. The achievement pushed US tech behemoths to question America’s standing in the AI race against China.

neutral.headline: Scarlett Johansson demands action after stars targeted in AI deepfake
neutral.summary: A deepfake video of Scarlett Johansson was widely circulated on social media this week. The AI video showed an image of Johansson in a T-shirt emblazoned with a hand and middle finger extended, a Jewish star and Kanye West’s name. Though fake, the video implied she and others were responding to Westâs most recent antisemitic remarks.

neutral.headline:
Gallery
                    In pictures: The 149th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show
neutral.summary: Monty is the first giant schnauzer ever to win the dog show. The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show is the second-oldest continuous sporting event in the United States. More than 2,500 dogs, representing all 50 states, competed this year.

neutral.headline: This photographer is chasing the âghostsâ of Venice
neutral.summary: Photographer Michael Kenna's new book, ‘Venezia. Memorie e Tracce,’ or  ‘The Floating City’ contains around 120 black-and-white photos by Kenna, taken during his regular visits over the past four decades. “It’s one of those places you almost obsess about when you’re not there,” he says.

neutral.headline: West Texas measles outbreak doubles to 48 cases
neutral.summary: The first two cases were identified in late January. Surrounding counties have also reported cases. All of the cases are in unvaccinated people or those who have unknown vaccination status. All experienced an onset of symptoms in the past three weeks.

neutral.headline: Tip us off
neutral.summary: SecureDrop allows you to safely send us messages and documents. All we get is what you send us, and a codename that allows us to reply to you. To prevent interception at our end, we decrypt what you sent us on a computer that is kept.

neutral.headline: From our global editions
neutral.summary: The Guardian now offers five different global editions of its news website and apps. These editions showcase all the journalism produced by our reporters and offices across the world. Most readers are automatically directed to their local homepage based on their location. To choose a different homepage to be your default, you can select any of the five editions.

neutral.headline: Blind date: ‘I really enjoyed chatting to her – even when she critiqued my dating app profile!’
neutral.summary: Matthew, 24, a tax consultant, meets Izzy, 25, an advertising executive. Izzy was smiley and chatty from the offset and conversation flowed until the end of the date. Matthew enjoyed listening to her chat even when she was giving him constructive criticism on his dating app profile.

neutral.headline: Keown apologises to Van Nistelrooy for infamous Old Trafford ‘shenanigans’
neutral.summary: Martin Keown and Ruud van Nistelrooy came to blows during a memorable encounter between the Gunners and Manchester United 22 years ago. The Football Association subsequently charged both clubs with the incident etched into the history books. The TNT Sports pundit Keown was at the King Power Stadium to cover   and caught up with Foxes boss Van Nistelsoy before kick-off.

neutral.headline: Donald Trump
neutral.summary: Donald Trump is the 45th and 47th president of the United States. He is the son of Fred Trump and the daughter of Fred and Gladys Trump. He was born in New York and grew up in New Jersey. He has been married three times and has two children.

neutral.headline: Sign up for our email
neutral.summary: Archie Bland and Nimo Omer take you through the top stories and what they mean. This week's top stories include the death of Osama bin Laden and the arrest of 9/11 suspects in New York. Watch the full interview with Archie Bland on Sunday night at 10pm on CNN.

neutral.headline: Work for us
neutral.summary: Guardian News & Media is one of the world's leading media organisations. We produce award-winning journalism and are committed to equality and diversity. We are the home of The Guardian, the world’s oldest and most successful newspaper.

For confidential support on suicide matters call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch, see www.samaritans.org for details.

neutral.headline: Did You Follow the News This Week? Take Our Quiz.
neutral.summary: Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers. Who ordered prosecutors this week to drop corruption charges against New York City's mayor? The Justice Department Gov. Kathy Hochul The Supreme Court Turkish officials Eric Adams President Trump on Monday imposed tariffs of 25 percent on all imports of which two raw materials? Gold and silver Lithium and cobalt Silicon and gallium Steel and aluminum Timber and wood pulp

neutral.summary: CNN.com will feature iReporter photos in a weekly Travel Snapshots gallery. Please submit your best shots of New York for next week. Visit CNN.com/Travel next Wednesday for a new gallery of snapshots from around the world.

neutral.headline: CookingRecipes and guides
neutral.summary: Make these recipes when you need a fast, flavorful meal. Chocolate Pound Cake With Strawberry Whipped Cream is simple to make, but has a tangy depth of flavor thanks to a cream cheese–infused batter. Make these recipes for up to three hours.

neutral.headline: WirecutterProduct recommendations
neutral.summary: Use promo code WCTIDY25 for 25% off $1740   Use promo code WIRECUTTER (king and Cal king) $11   Free Sephora Beauty Insider membership required by  Christine Cyr Clisset, Caira Blackwell, Rosie Guerin, and Abigail Keel.

neutral.headline: The CrosswordGet clued in with wordplay, every day.
neutral.summary: Since the launch of The Crossword in 1942, The Times has captivated solvers by providing engaging word and logic games. In 2014, we introduced The Mini Crossword, followed by Spelling Bee, Letter Boxed and Tiles. In early 2022, we proudly added Wordle to our collection. Since then we have created Connections and Strands.

neutral.headline: Israel, Hamas complete 6th swap; 4 Palestinian detainees hospitalised
neutral.summary: CNN.com will feature iReporter photos in a weekly Travel Snapshots gallery. Please submit your best shots for next week's gallery. Visit CNN.com/Travel each week for a new gallery of snapshots. Click here for the gallery.

neutral.headline: Palestinians burn ‘humiliating’ shirts after release from Israeli prisons
neutral.summary: 369 Palestinians were released in exchange for three captives in Gaza. Israel's move to force the released Palestinians to wear shirts with a Star of David logo and "we will not forget or forgive" written in Arabic has prompted anger and been slammed as a “racist crime”

neutral.headline: Palestinians burn ‘humiliating’ shirts after release from Israeli prisons
neutral.summary: 369 Palestinians were released in exchange for three captives in Gaza. Israel's move to force the released Palestinians to wear shirts with a Star of David logo and "we will not forget or forgive" written in Arabic has prompted anger and been slammed as a “racist crime”

neutral.headline: US says Europe to be excluded from Russia-Ukraine peace talks
neutral.summary: General Keith Kellogg made the announcement on Saturday after the US sent a questionnaire to European capitals to ask what they could contribute to security guarantees for Kyiv. Trump took European allies by surprise this week by calling Russia’s President Vladimir Putin without consulting them or Kyiv beforehand.

neutral.headline: Thousands take part in London rally against Trump’s Gaza plan
neutral.summary: Protesters waved Palestinian flags and brandished placards saying 'hands off Gaza' Several thousand people walked from Whitehall, in Westminster, to the US embassy in Nine Elms, in southwest London. Earlier this month, Trump’s suggestion that the US could redevelop the embattled enclave attracted global condemnation. His proposal aims to resettle Palestinians elsewhere, with no plan for them to return.

neutral.headline: Israel frees hundreds of Palestinians after captives in Gaza released
neutral.summary: Hamas released 369 Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails on Saturday. It is the largest number of Palestinians to be freed since the beginning of the truce. Most of the prisoners were arrested in Gaza and will be sent back. About 10 will be released in the occupied West Bank, one in occupied East Jerusalem.

neutral.headline: ‘Please don’t do this’: Afghan families in Pakistan caught in crackdown
neutral.summary: Salima Ahmad is an Afghan citizen living in Pakistan since 2022. On February 7, two days after their visas expired, her fears became reality. A group of police officials, including female officers, raided her rented house. Despite her pleas and attempts to show that their passports had been sent for visa renewal, the police took her husband away.

neutral.headline: Can AI and automated planes help prevent plane crashes?
neutral.summary: More than 100 people have been killed in air crashes this year already. Fatal incidents in the first two months of the new year came after last year was declared one of the deadliest in aviation history. Industry experts and investigations concur that human error is to blame for a majority of crashes.

neutral.headline: Left in the lurch: Asylum seekers respond to Trump’s CBP One cancellation
neutral.summary: Giovanni Martino was only 17 when he fled Venezuela due to its economic collapse. At age 23 and with no legal immigration documents, Martino undertook the perilous trek north. His wife and children had the luxury of Colombian passports: They could fly to Mexico City without a visa.

neutral.headline: Germany rebuffs ‘dictated peace’ for Ukraine at Munich security summit
neutral.summary: Scholz said a peace deal to end the three-year Russian invasion cannot be imposed on Kyiv. Comments came as European leaders have been trying to make sense of a tough new line from the new US administration on Ukraine’s future.

neutral.headline: Israel, Hamas complete 6th swap; 4 Palestinian detainees hospitalised
neutral.summary: CNN.com will feature iReporter photos in a weekly Travel Snapshots gallery. Please submit your best shots for next week's gallery. Visit CNN.com/Travel each week for a new gallery of snapshots. Click here for the gallery.

neutral.headline: US says Europe to be excluded from Russia-Ukraine peace talks
neutral.summary: General Keith Kellogg made the announcement on Saturday after the US sent a questionnaire to European capitals to ask what they could contribute to security guarantees for Kyiv. Trump took European allies by surprise this week by calling Russia’s President Vladimir Putin without consulting them or Kyiv beforehand.

neutral.headline: Palestinians burn ‘humiliating’ shirts after release from Israeli prisons
neutral.summary: 369 Palestinians were released in exchange for three captives in Gaza. Israel's move to force the released Palestinians to wear shirts with a Star of David logo and "we will not forget or forgive" written in Arabic has prompted anger and been slammed as a “racist crime”

neutral.headline: ‘Please don’t do this’: Afghan families in Pakistan caught in crackdown
neutral.summary: Salima Ahmad is an Afghan citizen living in Pakistan since 2022. On February 7, two days after their visas expired, her fears became reality. A group of police officials, including female officers, raided her rented house. Despite her pleas and attempts to show that their passports had been sent for visa renewal, the police took her husband away.

neutral.headline: Thousands take part in London rally against Trump’s Gaza plan
neutral.summary: Protesters waved Palestinian flags and brandished placards saying 'hands off Gaza' Several thousand people walked from Whitehall, in Westminster, to the US embassy in Nine Elms, in southwest London. Earlier this month, Trump’s suggestion that the US could redevelop the embattled enclave attracted global condemnation. His proposal aims to resettle Palestinians elsewhere, with no plan for them to return.

neutral.headline: Germany rebuffs ‘dictated peace’ for Ukraine at Munich security summit
neutral.summary: Scholz said a peace deal to end the three-year Russian invasion cannot be imposed on Kyiv. Comments came as European leaders have been trying to make sense of a tough new line from the new US administration on Ukraine’s future.

neutral.headline: THE FIFTH ESTATE
neutral.summary: An investigation by CBC’s The Fifth Estate uncovered a key internal document. The document provides a minute-by-minute account of how authorities believe the 2023 gold heist at Toronto's Pearson International Airport was planned and executed. It alleges a highly organized group of individuals relied heavily on a well-placed insider.

neutral.headline: Second Opinion
neutral.summary: The mineral is essential for the body to make thyroid hormones. Table salt is one major source of iodine in Canada. Much of the soil in Canada is iodine-deficient. Not having enough iodine could lead to a variety of health conditions, like goitres.

neutral.headline: CBC Investigates
neutral.summary: Home renovation company AGM Renovations says it is closing down. CEO Ivan Atanasov says CBC News coverage damaged company's reputation. CBC reported two stories on AGM this month. Customers say Holmes' endorsement influenced their decision to hire AGM.

neutral.headline: The GST holiday ends on Saturday. Did it make a difference for shoppers and businesses?
neutral.summary: The federal government imposed the temporary tax break on Dec. 14, 2024. It applies to restaurant meals, some alcohol, children's toys and clothing, magazines, newspapers and other goods. Government officials said it was a way to offset some of the costs of the holiday season.

neutral.headline: Gigatonnes of carbon are stored in under-protected areas
neutral.summary: 17 per cent of peatlands are currently protected, according to new research. The UN estimates as much as   are stored there, as decaying organic material gets trapped inside a water-rich environment. Peatlands also provide a habitat to a range of plant and animal species.

neutral.headline: How one community in Guatemala lives off the forest, while protecting it for the future
neutral.summary: The Maya Biosphere Reserve is part of one of the largest tracts of rainforest in Central America. More than 80,000 hectares of land are cared for by the villagers of Uaxactún. The community lives off the forest, while protecting it for the future.

neutral.headline: Second Opinion
neutral.summary: The mineral is essential for the body to make thyroid hormones. Table salt is one major source of iodine in Canada. Much of the soil in Canada is iodine-deficient. Not having enough iodine could lead to a variety of health conditions, like goitres.

neutral.headline: Canada announces changes to Jordan's Principle program, narrows range of eligible requests
neutral.summary: Canada has announced sweeping changes to a program designed to ensure First Nations kids get the care and supports they need, when they need them. The changes come almost a year after the federal government argued before the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal that requests were being made for non-urgent things. The CHRT said last month it was "quite concerned" about that problem.

neutral.headline: The GST holiday ends today. Did it make a difference for shoppers and businesses?
neutral.summary: The federal government imposed the temporary tax break on Dec. 14, 2024. It applies to restaurant meals, some alcohol, children's toys and clothing, magazines, newspapers and other goods. Government officials said it was a way to offset some of the costs of the holiday season.

neutral.headline: Donald Trump and the Kennedy Center controversy, explained
neutral.summary: Canadian author Louise Penny has pulled out of a book launch at the Kennedy Center. Penny said she would not launch the 20th instalment in her series of books at the venue. "It was, of course, going to be a career highlight," she said on Facebook.

negative.headline: New Delhi crowd crush
negative.summary: At least 18 people were killed in a crowd crush at a New Delhi railway station Saturday as passengers tried to board trains. The crush took place late Saturday night, when delays to two train services and an influx of passengers led to overcrowding. Many of those in the crowds are thought to have been heading to the  , the worldâs largest religious gathering.

negative.headline: 1979 cold case arrest
negative.summary: Deroshia Matthews, 26, and her son, Kamal, 7, were found dead in their home in 1979. Abdulmalik Husain, 68, formerly known as Louis Walker, was arrested Wednesday. Husain is charged with two counts of murder in connection with the deaths.

negative.headline: Ukrainians are fearful any Trump-brokered ceasefire will be full of concessions and false promises
negative.summary: Iryna Danilova has been in a Russian penal colony for two years. She was convicted of illegal possession of explosives and sentenced to seven years in prison. She suffers from constant headaches and is not allowed to sit or lie down during the day.

negative.headline:
Video
                    Honig on âincalculable damage on DOJâ
                        1:40
negative.summary: Three senior Justice Department officials in New York and Washington resigned instead of complying with orders from the Trump administration to dismiss the corruption case against New York City Mayor Eric Adams. CNN senior legal analyst Elie Honig weighs in on the crisis at the DOJ.

negative.headline: Ballerinaâs parents jailed for neglecting the daughter they bathed in attention but starved of food
negative.summary: The girl was so malnourished that doctors said she was at risk of cardiac arrest and death. Witnesses at the hospital said her parents treated her as if she were a small child. They took her to the bathroom, wiped her bottom, blew her nose and brushed her hair.

negative.headline: 5 people in upstate New York charged with murder after allegedly torturing, killing Minnesota transgender man
negative.summary: Five people have been arrested in connection with the disappearance and murder of a 24-year-old transgender man. New York State Police launched a missing persons investigation for Sam Nordquist on February 9. Human remains believed to be those of Nordquist were discovered on February 13 in a field in Yates County, about 50 miles southeast of Rochester.

negative.headline: White South Africans gather to support Trump and his claims that theyâre victims of racism
negative.summary: White South Africans gathered at the US Embassy in Pretoria by their own government. Many were from the Afrikaner community that Trump focused on in an executive order a week ago. Hundreds of protesters held placards that read âThank God for President Trumpâ�ai

negative.headline: Anxiety can be debilitating. Controlling it starts with this simple step, Martha Beck says
negative.summary: Sociologist and best-selling author says curiosity and creativity can act as antidotes to anxiety. Evidence shows a kind of toggle effect between creativity and anxiety, she explained. Disrupting the cycle of constant worry requires big shifts in how we relate to the world, argues Beck.

negative.headline: Isolated Indigenous man makes brief contact with outside world, then returns to tribe in the Amazon rainforest
negative.summary: The encounter occurred around 7 p.m. local time Wednesday in Bela Rosa, a community along the Purus River in the southwestern Amazon. Officials from Brazilâs Indigenous affairs agency, Funai, arrived soon after and took him to a nearby facility. Funai said in a   that the young man returned to the forest on Thursday afternoon.

negative.headline: âWorldâs clearest lakeâ is being threatened by tourists
negative.summary: Nelson Lakes National Park, in New Zealandâs South Island, is home to a magical blue-violet lake. It was first discovered by NgÄti Apa, a MÄ ori iwi, or tribe, who named it Rotomairewhenua. It became a sacred place where they cleansed the bones of the dead.

negative.headline: âYou get one split secondâ: The story behind a viral bird photo
negative.summary: James Crombie is an award-winning sports photographer by trade. He has covered three Olympic Games and usually shoots rugby and the Irish game of hurling. His only previous encounter with the short-tailed birds occurred when one fell into his fireplace after attempting to nest in the chimney.

negative.headline: Juvenile sea turtles âdanceâ when food is nearby
negative.summary: Earthâs inner core is 70% the size of the moon. Recent research suggested this dense center reversed its spin. Scientists inferred signs of deformation from earthquakes strong enough to reach the planet’s heart. Over time, changes to this innermost layer could impact the planet's magnetic field.

negative.headline: Trump wants to kill congestion pricing. But itâs working
negative.summary: President Donald Trump wants to end New York City’s landmark congestion pricing policy. Legal experts say Trump doesn’t have the power to end congestion pricing anyway. The federal government closely scrutinized and approved it, and courts have upheld it.

negative.headline: Cases in Louisiana and Texas could bring tensions between states over abortion to a head
negative.summary: Anti-abortion activists and aligned state and local officials are plotting cases that would force such a confrontation. Such a conflict could put abortion back at the high courtâs doorstep sooner than the justices may like. A warrant is now out for a New York doctor accused of unlawfully prescribing abortion pills.

negative.headline: âWe were usedâ: These immigrants followed the USâ rules but now feel betrayed
negative.summary: Janvier Ndagijimana and his family spent decades in refugee camps. They were finally allowed to travel to the US this year. The 52-year-old Congolese refugee arrived in Kentucky just six days before President Trump's inauguration.

negative.headline: OpenAI board rejects Elon Musk-led $97 billion purchase offer
negative.summary: OpenAI’s board of directors has formally rejected a $97.4 billion bid by Elon Musk and other investors to purchase the company. The statement marks the latest twist in a long-running feud between OpenAI and Musk over the ChatGPT maker.

negative.headline: Singles in this city pay the most to live alone
negative.summary: In the city that never sleeps, singles pay an average of $20,100 more per year to live alone. That’s according to an analysis from real estate platforms StreetEasy and Zillow, which owns the StreetEasy brand. Couples who live together in a one-bedroom apartment in New York City save a combined $40,200 per year on rent.

negative.headline: US retail spending plunged last month, falling for the first time since August
negative.summary: Retail sales plunged 0.9% in January from the prior month, the Commerce Department said Friday. Specialty stores and auto dealers were hit hardest, with spending falling 4.6% and 3%. US stocks were mostly flat Friday morning at market open, with all three major indexes up just 0.1%.

negative.headline: World No. 1 Jannik Sinner accepts three-month ban from tennis to settle doping case
negative.summary: Sinner will be banned from February 9 to May 4 after twice testing positive for banned substance Clostebol in March 2024. The 23-year-old will be eligible to play in the French Open. Sinner had previously avoided suspension from competition with the International Tennis Integrity Agency (ITIA) in August.

negative.headline: âWorldâs clearest lakeâ is being threatened by tourists
negative.summary: Nelson Lakes National Park, in New Zealandâs South Island, is home to a magical blue-violet lake. It was first discovered by NgÄti Apa, a MÄ ori iwi, or tribe, who named it Rotomairewhenua. It became a sacred place where they cleansed the bones of the dead.

negative.headline: Thousands call on Christieâs to cancel AI art auction in open letter
negative.summary: Nearly 4,000 people have signed an online letter calling on Christieâs New York to cancel the sale. The sale is the first of its kind for a major auction house. There are concerns that the programs used to create some generative digital pieces are trained on copyrighted work and exploit human artists.

negative.headline: 3 health conditions increase risk of liver damage if you drink, study says
negative.summary: Drinking alcohol if you have a large belly or diabetes more than doubles the risk of serious liver damage. Having high blood pressure and drinking nearly doubles therisk of liver damage, a new study found. Those are important health risks to consider, said Dr. Andrew Freeman, director of cardiovascular prevention.

negative.headline: Trump officials fired nuclear staff not realizing they oversee the countryâs weapons stockpile, sources say
negative.summary: Officials fired more than 300 staffers Thursday night at the National Nuclear Security Administration. The agency is tasked with managing the nationâs nuclear stockpile. An Energy Department spokesperson disputed the number of personnel affected. Some of the fired employees included NNSA staff who are on the ground at facilities where nuclear weapons are built.

negative.headline:
Exclusive
FEMA firings reveal tension and confusion within the Department of Homeland Security
negative.summary: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem issued a directive that the Federal Emergency Management Agency should stop sending money to non-governmental organizations. FEMA personnel were directed to continue sending those payments. Four FEMA employees, including its chief financial officer, were fired and accused by the Department of Homeland Security of circumventing leadership.

negative.headline: A mom and her child were killed in their Nebraska home 45 years ago. DNA helped authorities make an arrest in the cold case
negative.summary: Deroshia Matthews, 26, and her son, Kamal, 7, were found dead in their home in 1979. Abdulmalik Husain, 68, formerly known as Louis Walker, was arrested Wednesday. Husain is charged with two counts of murder in connection with the deaths.

negative.headline: The death of 2 homeless children in frigid Detroit raises questions about a flawed system in peril
negative.summary: Tateona Williams called the city of Detroit in November for help for her family. No one followed up, even after the city opened a new drop-in shelter for families. Two of Williams’ children were found dead in a van the family had been sleeping in.

negative.headline: Homeowner pleads guilty to shooting Black teen Ralph Yarl who rang the wrong doorbell
negative.summary: Andrew Lester was scheduled to stand trial next week on charges of first-degree assault and armed criminal action. Lester, who will be sentenced on March 7, was hunched over as he was wheeled into the courtroom, his hands folded. The then-16-year-old survived and has since graduated from high school.

negative.headline: Black Hawk helicopterâs altimeter may have been inaccurate
negative.summary: Preliminary analysis of flight data and voice recorder on board a Black Hawk suggests altimeter may have been inaccurate. Pilot and instructor read out two different altitudes shortly before crash, NTSB chair says. Radio altimeter on board the Black Hawk at the time of the deadly midair collision read 278 feet.

negative.headline: At least 18 dead in crush at New Delhi train station as crowds head for religious festival, Indian media reports
negative.summary: At least 18 people were killed in a crowd crush at a New Delhi railway station Saturday as passengers tried to board trains. The crush took place late Saturday night, when delays to two train services and an influx of passengers led to overcrowding. Many of those in the crowds are thought to have been heading to the  , the worldâs largest religious gathering.

negative.headline: British couple motorbiking around the world detained in Iran
negative.summary: Craig and Lindsay Foreman are being held on suspicion of security-related charges. The couple had been on a motorcycle tour around the world. The last post from the couple was in early January. The family say they are determined to secure their safe return.

negative.headline: Three Israeli hostages and hundreds of Palestinian detainees freed after dispute threatened Gaza ceasefire
negative.summary: The hostages were released in Khan Younis, southern Gaza. It is the sixth such exchange under the truce between Israel and Hamas. The men appeared to be in better health than the three hostages released the previous week, whose condition was not known.

negative.headline: Man stabs 5 people in Austria killing 14-year-old in what police describe as a random attack
negative.summary: The suspect is a Syrian national with legal residence in Austria, police say. The victims were all men, with two seriously injured and two sustaining minor injuries. A motive was not immediately known, police said. A 42-year-old man who witnessed the incident from his car helped to prevent things from getting worse.

negative.headline:
Video
                    See puppy reunite with owner after being lost in snow
                        1:36
negative.summary: Retired New York State police investigator Chad Tavernia has been using a high-tech thermal imaging drone to help people find their missing dogs. Tavernia recently rescued a 10-month puppy after she went missing in the snow for 34 hours.

negative.headline:
Gallery
                    Elon Muskâs son steals spotlight. Bus crash kills scores in Guatemala. The week in photos
negative.summary: The Philadelphia Eagles beat the Kansas City Chiefs 40-22. The game was a rematch of the Super Bowl two years ago, which the Chiefs won. Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts threw for two touchdowns and ran for one on his way to winning.

negative.headline: This uncomfortable portrait of femininity has resonated for four decades
negative.summary: Jo Ann Callis took a photograph of a woman with her head thrown back, her neck taut and tied with a bow looped together from the thin baby blue straps of her white lace dress. Though she made the image four and a half decades ago, it seems strikingly contemporary, a timeless symbol on the strictures of femininity. It is currently exhibiting in the group show at Rose Gallery in Santa Monica, California.

negative.headline: Jane Doe drops sexual assault lawsuit against Jay-Z and Sean âDiddyâ Combs
negative.summary: A Jane Doe who alleged Sean âDiddyâ�ai Combs and Jay-Z sexually assaulted her 25 years ago has withdrawn her lawsuit against them. In a notice of voluntary dismissal filed Friday, attorneys for the woman dropped the lawsuit with prejudice, preventing it from being re-filed.

negative.headline: JD Vance’s Munich speech laid bare the collapse of the transatlantic alliance
negative.summary: The US vice-president was hypocritical and insensitive, but bracingly clear in his resetting of relationships. Since 1963, the Munich Security Conference has seen many consequential speeches, notably Vladimir Putin announcing in 2007 that Russia would never accept a subordinate role in the new world order.

negative.headline: Offshore worker Robbie Robson was bludgeoned to death on an oil rig. Was it a random attack or does the industry have questions to answer?
negative.summary: Robbie Robson, 38, a British offshore worker, travelled to Qatar for an eight-week contract in the oilfields of the Persian Gulf. Six weeks later, he was dead, and a co-worker charged with his murder. Now his partner is struggling to make sense of what happened.

negative.headline: ConnectionsGroup words that share a common thread.
negative.summary: Since the launch of The Crossword in 1942, The Times has captivated solvers by providing engaging word and logic games. In 2014, we introduced The Mini Crossword, followed by Spelling Bee, Letter Boxed and Tiles. In early 2022, we proudly added Wordle to our collection. Since then we have created Connections and Strands.

negative.headline: StrandsUncover hidden words and reveal the theme.
negative.summary: Since the launch of The Crossword in 1942, The Times has captivated solvers by providing engaging word and logic games. In 2014, we introduced The Mini Crossword, followed by Spelling Bee, Letter Boxed and Tiles. In early 2022, we proudly added Wordle to our collection. Since then we have created Connections and Strands.

negative.headline: Four Palestinians released by Israel hospitalised in critical condition
negative.summary: Four Palestinians released as part of a ceasefire deal are in critical condition. They have been hospitalised in the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah. Israel released 369 Palestinians   in exchange for three captives in Gaza. Many Palestinians appeared to have lost an enormous amount of weight while in custody.

negative.headline: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events – day 1,088
negative.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that Russian President Vladimir Putin is attempting to create conditions to frame Putin as the victor over US President Donald Trump in negotiations. He made the comments during his address at the Munich Security Conference on Sunday.

negative.headline: Children among 15 killed in crush at New Delhi train station in India
negative.summary: Ten women and three children among at least 15 people killed in crowd crush. Thousands of Hindu pilgrims waited to board trains to attend the annual festival. Incident unfolded on Saturday night at about 8pm local time (14:30 GMT) India’s Minister of Railways Ashwini Vaishnaw said four trains had been deployed to ‘evacuate’ a sudden and unprecedented surge of travellers.

negative.headline: Despite ceasefire, Israel still destroying homes in Gaza
negative.summary: Satellite images show Israel has built sand fortifications across the Rafah crossing. The crossing between Egypt and Gaza at Rafah was closed by Israel in May 2024. Israel has been digging in in the 14-km (8.7-mile) strip of land.

negative.headline: Lives on the line: Low pay has US wildland firefighters quitting
negative.summary: A camper in Washington State’s Okanogan National Forest has left a campfire unattended. The previous winter was one of the driest in decades and the summer temperature has been near record highs. The next morning, a fire crew that has spent the night mobilising to fight a 1,000-acre wildfire nearby is redirected to the emerging Thirtymile Fire.

negative.headline: Protests over train station collapse grip Serbia, demand government action
negative.summary: Tens of thousands of students have descended on the town of Kragujevac. Latest in a series of protests to rock the Balkan country after the deadly collapse of a train station roof last year. Fifteen people were   were killed on November 1 when a roof collapsed at the Novi Sad train station.

negative.headline: ‘Over the precipice’: UN chief sounds alarm on DR Congo fighting
negative.summary: UN chief Antonio Guterres says the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s (DRC) ‘territorial integrity’ must be preserved after M23 fighters. Addressing an African Union (AU) summit in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa on Saturday, he said a “regional escalation must be avoided at all costs’

negative.headline: What they lost: Families in terror as Israel raids West Bank camps
negative.summary: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers poured out of Far’a refugee camp in the occupied West Bank. Orders shouted in Hebrew blared from speakers, overlapping with the soldiers’ commands. “Open the door! Get out now!” they yelled.

negative.headline: Is Russia running out of weapons and manpower for its war in Ukraine?
negative.summary: Donkeys are the newest mode of transportation some Russian military units have begun using on the front lines of eastern Ukraine. Last year, Russia began using motorcycles, dirt bikes, electric scooters and civilian cars for frontal attacks on Ukrainian positions. Observers say the downgrading reflects a growing trend that significantly hobbles Russia’s already slow advance on the main theatre.

negative.headline: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events – day 1,088
negative.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that Russian President Vladimir Putin is attempting to create conditions to frame Putin as the victor over US President Donald Trump in negotiations. He made the comments during his address at the Munich Security Conference on Sunday.

negative.headline: Four Palestinians released by Israel hospitalised in critical condition
negative.summary: Four Palestinians released as part of a ceasefire deal are in critical condition. They have been hospitalised in the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah. Israel released 369 Palestinians   in exchange for three captives in Gaza. Many Palestinians appeared to have lost an enormous amount of weight while in custody.

negative.headline: Hamas frees 3 hostages, Israel releases hundreds of prisoners as fragile ceasefire holds
negative.summary: Iair Horn, Sagui Dekel-Chen and Sasha Troufanov arrived at a release site. They were led onto a stage with men armed with automatic rifles standing on each side. Dozens of armed militants were deployed at the site of the release. Some Hamas fighters were carrying rifles seized from the Israeli military.

negative.headline: Why major countries can't agree on how to regulate artificial intelligence
negative.summary: More than 60 nations gathered in Paris this week for an AI summit. The European Union has pursued aggressive regulation of Big Tech. Meanwhile, the Trump administration has made tech deregulation a central part of its agenda. The U.S. opted not to — but so did the U.K., which raised eyebrows among attendees and in the media.

negative.headline: AFN regional chiefs accuse national chief of stoking division on child welfare reform
negative.summary: National Chief Cindy Woodhouse Nepinak asked how the society plans to improve on a $47.8-billion federal offer to overhaul the system. "It is Canada — not the Caring Society — that must be held accountable," the regional chiefs wrote on Jan. 15.

negative.headline: Hamas frees 3 hostages, Israel releases hundreds of prisoners as fragile ceasefire holds
negative.summary: Iair Horn, Sagui Dekel-Chen and Sasha Troufanov arrived at a release site. They were led onto a stage with men armed with automatic rifles standing on each side. Dozens of armed militants were deployed at the site of the release. Some Hamas fighters were carrying rifles seized from the Israeli military.
